snippet: The United Methodist Church at its convention voted against changing language in its book of laws and doctrines that calls homosexuality “incompatible with Christian teaching.”
abstract: United Methodist Church votes at its convention in Tampa, Fla, against changing long-contested language in its book of laws and doctrines that calls homosexuality 'incompatible with Christian teaching'; delegates also defeat a compromise proposed by gay rights advocates that would allow Methodists to openly differ with the doctrine. (M)0
lead_paragraph: The United Methodist Church at its convention in Tampa, Fla., on Thursday voted against changing long-contested language in its book of laws and doctrines that calls homosexuality ''incompatible with Christian teaching.'' The vote was 61 percent to 39 percent against the change to the church's Book of Discipline. The delegates also defeated by a similar margin a compromise proposed by gay rights advocates, which said that Methodists could acknowledge their differences on homosexuality while still living together as a church.
